speaker: Doctor
text: I've reviewed your chart, and I must say, your symptoms do sound quite concerning. Can you tell me, when did you first start noticing that your son was having trouble feeding?

speaker: Patient
text: "About 3 days ago, I think. He just started fussing a lot more than usual when I try to feed him, and sometimes he'll pull away from the bottle or breast."

speaker: Doctor
text: That's helpful to know. Has your son's weight been steadily decreasing since the feeding difficulties began, or has it been more of a gradual decline?

speaker: Patient
text: "Honestly, his weight gain has been steady, but it's just been really hard to get him to eat. My pediatrician said he's still gaining weight, just not as much as he used to."

speaker: Doctor
text: His weight has been steadily decreasing over the past 2 months, and we've had to supplement with formula to keep his weight stable.

speaker: Patient
text: "My mom says that when she tries to touch my tummy, I get really upset and cry a lot. It feels like it hurts when she does that."

speaker: Doctor
text: I see that the weight decline has been steady. Have you noticed any vomiting or regurgitation after feeding, which might be contributing to the weight loss?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, I don't think so. He doesn't spit up or anything like that, but like I said, he's really fussy when I try to feed him, and sometimes he'll just push the bottle or breast away and arch his back."

speaker: Doctor
text: Has there been any blood or bile in the vomit, or is it just formula and breast milk?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, there's no blood or anything like that in his spit-up, just formula and milk. But like I said, he's really fussy and uncomfortable when I try to feed him."

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to know, has your son been experiencing any abdominal pain or discomfort that might be related to the feeding difficulties?

speaker: Patient
text: "Sometimes when my mom or dad holds me close and rubs my tummy, I get really upset and start crying. It feels like something is hurting inside me."

speaker: Doctor
text: I've made a note of that abdominal discomfort. Have you noticed any changes in your son's bowel movements, such as diarrhea or constipation, that could be contributing to the abdominal distension?

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't think so. My poop is usually pretty normal, but it's been a little harder to tell lately since I've been eating less. But my mom says it looks okay, like it usually does."

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to perform a physical exam to assess the abdominal distension and look for any signs of tenderness or guarding. Can you please have your son lie down on the examination table for me?

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't wanna lie down. Can I just sit up?"

speaker: Doctor
text: I've finished the physical exam, and I notice that your son's abdomen is indeed distended, but there's no palpable mass. I'd like to ask, has your son had any episodes of intestinal obstruction or gas buildup that might have caused him to cry or be uncomfortable?

speaker: Patient
text: "Sometimes when I'm being fed, I let out a really loud cry and my mom says my tummy feels really tight and hard. It feels like there's a lot of air inside me and it hurts."

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your son's symptoms and physical exam results. Have you noticed any episodes of projectile vomiting, where the vomit shoots out quickly and forcefully after feeding?

speaker: Patient
text: "Sometimes when I'm being fed, I get really upset and start crying, and then I let out a big, loud wail and my mom says it sounds like I'm trying to scream. It feels like my tummy is going to burst or something."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any other signs of illness, such as fever, lethargy, or irritability, in your son that might be related to the feeding difficulties and abdominal distension?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, when my mom holds me close and talks to me in a soft voice, I usually calm down and stop crying. But when she touches my tummy or tries to feed me, it's like I just can't relax and I get really upset."

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken all that information into account. Have you noticed any improvement in your son's symptoms when he's upright or standing, as opposed to when he's lying down or feeding?

speaker: Patient
text: "When I'm sitting up or standing, I feel a little bit better, I think. It's easier to breathe and I don't feel as tight in my tummy."

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to ask, have you noticed any significant changes in your son's appetite or interest in feeding since the feeding difficulties began?

speaker: Patient
text: "Actually, he seems less interested in feeding now than he was before. He used to love eating and would drink from the bottle or breast all the time, but now he just gets really upset and fussy when I try to feed him."

speaker: Doctor
text: I've reviewed all the information you've provided so far. I'd like to ask, have you noticed any significant changes in your son's urine output or have you observed any signs of dehydration, such as dry mouth or sunken eyes?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, I don't think so. My mom says that my diaper is still getting wet pretty regularly, and I don't seem to be as dry as I used to be when I'm not eating. But sometimes when I'm really upset and crying, my mom says my eyes look a little bit sunken, like they're sinking in."

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your son's decreased urine output and potential dehydration. Have you been giving him fluids regularly to keep him hydrated?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yes, my mom gives me water and formula to drink, and she says I'm getting enough fluids. But sometimes when she tries to give me a bottle, I get really upset and won't drink it."

speaker: Doctor
text: Has your son been experiencing any episodes of constipation or hard stools that might be contributing to the abdominal distension and feeding difficulties?

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't think so, but my poop has been really hard and dry sometimes. It feels like it's been stuck inside me, but my mom says it's coming out okay."

speaker: Doctor
text: I've asked 16 questions so far. I need to ask a few more to narrow down the possible causes of your son's symptoms. Have you noticed any family history of gastrointestinal issues or other medical conditions that might be relevant to your son's case?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, I don't think so. My parents and grandparents are all healthy, and I don't know of anyone in my family who has had any serious medical problems."

speaker: Doctor
text: I see.  That's helpful to know. Are there any other family members who have had similar issues with feeding or abdominal problems in the past?

speaker: Patient
text: "No, I don't think so. My family is pretty healthy, and I don't know of anyone who's ever had problems like this."

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of the family history. Have you noticed any improvement or worsening of your son's symptoms over the past few days, particularly after the most recent feeding supplements?

speaker: Patient
text: "Honestly, it seems like things have been getting a little worse over the past few days. He's been crying even more when I try to feed him, and it's harder to get him to drink his formula. Sometimes it feels like he's in a lot of pain when I'm trying to feed him."

speaker: Doctor
text: I've reviewed your final answers, and I must say, I've gathered quite a bit of information. Before I make a diagnosis, I'd like to request a few test results to further clarify the situation. REQUEST TEST: Abdominal Ultrasound, and also, can you please provide the results of a complete blood count (CBC) and a comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP)?
